message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The Origins and Psychology of Human Cooperation
Paper Abstract: Humans are an ultrasocial species. This sociality, however, cannot be fully explained by the canonical approaches found in evolutionary biology, psychology, or economics. Understanding our unique social psychology requires accounting not only for the breadth and intensity of human cooperation but also for the variation found across societies, over history, and among behavioral domains. Here, we introduce an expanded evolutionary approach that considers how genetic and cultural evolution, and their interaction, may have shaped both the reliably developing features of our minds and the well-documented differences in cultural psychologies around the globe. We review the major evolutionary mechanisms that have been proposed to explain human cooperation, including kinship, reciprocity, reputation, signaling, and punishment; we discuss key culture–gene coevolutionary hypotheses, such as those surrounding self-domestication and norm psychology; and we consider the role of religions and marriage systems. Empirically, we synthesize experimental and observational evidence from studies of children and adults from diverse societies with research among nonhuman primates.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.
List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

Web search results for query: "cultural evolution"

Links: [{"title":"Cultural evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_evolution"},{"title":"Sociocultural evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociocultural_evolution"},{"title":"Wikipedia:WikiProject Cultural Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Cultural_Evolution"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Cultural Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:WikiProject_Cultural_Evolution"},{"title":"Multilineal evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilineal_evolution"},{"title":"Talk:Cultural evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Cultural_evolution"},{"title":"Leslie White - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leslie_White"},{"title":"Cliodynamics (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cliodynamics_(journal)"},{"title":"Russell Gray - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russell_Gray"},{"title":"Sergey Gavrilets - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sergey_Gavrilets"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of cultural evolution:

## Definition and Scope

Cultural evolution is an evolutionary theory of social change.(no content)It follows from the definition of culture as "information capable of affecting individuals' behavior that they acquire from other members of their species through teaching, imitation and other forms of social transmission".(no content)Cultural evolution is the change of this information over time, using concepts like cultural variants, transmission mechanisms, and selective pressures to model how ideas, behaviors, and technologies spread and change over time.

## Historical Development

Cultural evolution, historically also known as sociocultural evolution, was originally developed in the 19th century by anthropologists stemming from Charles Darwin's research on evolution.(no content)Today, cultural evolution has become the basis for a growing field of scientific research in the social sciences, including anthropology, economics, psychology, and organizational studies.

## Theoretical Approaches

There have been a number of different approaches to the study of cultural evolution, including dual inheritance theory, sociocultural evolution, memetics, cultural evolutionism, and other variants on cultural selection theory.

## Modern Understanding

More recent approaches focus on changes specific to individual societies and reject the idea that cultures differ primarily according to how far each one has moved along some presumed linear scale of social progress. This represents a shift away from older 19th-century ideas that all cultures progress through universal stages.

Web search results for query: "evolutionary biology"

Links: [{"title":"Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Ecology and evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecology_and_Evolutionary_Biology"},{"title":"Portal:Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Journal of Evolutionary Biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Evolutionary_Biology"},{"title":"European Society for Evolutionary Biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Society_for_Evolutionary_Biology"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary biology journals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_biology_journals"},{"title":"Glossary of genetics and evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_genetics_and_evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Planck_Institute_for_Evolutionary_Biology"},{"title":"Index of evolutionary biology articles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Index_of_evolutionary_biology_articles"}]

## Search Results for "Evolutionary Biology"

Here's an overview of evolutionary biology based on the search results:

### Definition
Evolutionary biology is a subfield of biology that analyzes the four mechanisms of evolution: natural selection, mutation, genetic drift, and gene flow.(no content)The purpose of evolutionary biology is to observe the diversity of life on Earth.

### Historical Development
The idea of evolution by natural selection was proposed by Charles Darwin in 1859, but evolutionary biology, as an academic discipline in its own right, emerged during the period of the modern synthesis in the 1930s and 1940s.(no content)The discipline of evolutionary biology emerged through what Julian Huxley called the modern synthesis of understanding, from previously unrelated fields of biological research, such as genetics and ecology, systematics, and paleontology.

### Research Methods
Evolutionary biology explains diversity between species by analyzing changes in a few individuals within a population over multiple generations. The purpose of this subfield is to determine how genetic variation develops, how it is inherited, and how the evolutionary mechanisms shape a population's genetic composition.

### Modern Research
The newer field of evolutionary developmental biology ("evo-devo") investigates how embryogenesis is controlled, thus yielding a wider synthesis that integrates developmental biology with the fields of study covered by the earlier evolutionary synthesis.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "kinship"

Links: [{"title":"Cognatic kinship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognatic_kinship"},{"title":"Kinship terminology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinship_terminology"},{"title":"Kinship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinship"},{"title":"Family and Kinship in East London - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Family_and_Kinship_in_East_London"},{"title":"Collateral (kinship) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collateral_(kinship)"},{"title":"Milk kinship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milk_kinship"},{"title":"Fictive kinship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fictive_kinship"},{"title":"Chinese kinship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_kinship"},{"title":"Dyadic kinship term - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyadic_kinship_term"},{"title":"Prohibited degree of kinship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prohibited_degree_of_kinship"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about kinship:

## Definition and Scope

In anthropology, kinship is the web of social relationships that form an important part of the lives of all humans in all societies. Kinship can also refer to a principle by which individuals or groups of individuals are organized into social groups, roles, categories and genealogy by means of kinship terminologies.

## Types of Kinship

Kinship relationships can be understood in several ways:

**Consanguinity and Affinity**: Family is a group of people affiliated by consanguinity (by recognized birth), affinity (by marriage), or co-residence/shared consumption.

**Fictive Kinship**: Fictive kinship is a term used by anthropologists and ethnographers to describe forms of kinship or social ties that are based on neither consanguineal (blood ties) nor affinal ("by marriage") ties. Examples of chosen kin include godparents, adopted children, and close family friends.

## Kinship Terminology Systems

Kinship terminology is the system used in languages to refer to the persons to whom an individual is related through kinship. Different societies classify kinship relations differently and therefore use different systems of kinship terminology; for example, some languages distinguish between consanguine and affinal uncles, whereas others have only one word to refer to both a father and his brothers.

## Broader Meanings

In a more general sense, kinship may refer to a similarity or affinity between entities on the basis of some or all of their characteristics that are under focus. This may be due to a shared ontological origin, a shared historical or cultural connection, or some other perceived shared features that connect the two entities.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about kinship:

## Definition and Scope

In anthropology, kinship is the web of social relationships that form an important part of the lives of all humans in all societies. Kinship can also refer to a principle by which individuals or groups of individuals are organized into social groups, roles, categories and genealogy by means of kinship terminologies.

## Types of Kinship

Kinship relationships can be understood in several ways:

**Consanguinity and Affinity**: Family is a group of people affiliated by consanguinity (by recognized birth), affinity (by marriage), or co-residence/shared consumption.

**Fictive Kinship**: Fictive kinship is a term used by anthropologists and ethnographers to describe forms of kinship or social ties that are based on neither consanguineal (blood ties) nor affinal ("by marriage") ties. Examples of chosen kin include godparents, adopted children, and close family friends.

## Kinship Terminology Systems

Kinship terminology is the system used in languages to refer to the persons to whom an individual is related through kinship. Different societies classify kinship relations differently and therefore use different systems of kinship terminology; for example, some languages distinguish between consanguine and affinal uncles, whereas others have only one word to refer to both a father and his brothers.

## Broader Meanings

In a more general sense, kinship may refer to a similarity or affinity between entities on the basis of some or all of their characteristics that are under focus. This may be due to a shared ontological origin, a shared historical or cultural connection, or some other perceived shared features that connect the two entities.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about psychology:

## Definition

Psychology is the scientific study of behavior and mind. Its subject matter includes the behavior of humans and nonhumans, both conscious and unconscious phenomena, and mental processes such as thoughts, feelings, and motives.

## Scope and Academic Discipline

Psychology is an academic discipline of immense scope, crossing the boundaries between the natural and social sciences.(no content)Psychologists are involved in research on perception, cognition, attention, emotion, intelligence, subjective experiences, motivation, brain functioning, and personality.

## Areas of Research

Biological psychologists seek an understanding of the emergent properties of brains, linking the discipline to neuroscience. As social scientists, psychologists aim to understand the behavior of individuals and groups.

## Professional Practice

Many psychologists are involved in some kind of therapeutic role, practicing psychotherapy in clinical, counseling, or school settings. Other psychologists conduct scientific research on a wide range of topics related to mental processes and behavior. Typically the latter group of psychologists work in academic settings (e.g., universities, medical schools, or hospitals).

## Etymology

The word psychology derives from the Greek word psyche, for spirit or soul. The latter part of the word psychology derives from -λογία -logia, which means "study" or "research".

Links: [{"title":"Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation"},{"title":"Shanghai Cooperation Organisation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation"},{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Japan International Cooperation Agency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan_International_Cooperation_Agency"},{"title":"Cooperation (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation_(evolution)"},{"title":"Mekong–Ganga Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mekong–Ganga_Cooperation"},{"title":"Permanent Structured Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permanent_Structured_Cooperation"},{"title":"Organisation of Islamic Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation"},{"title":"Cooperative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative"},{"title":"Economy of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_the_Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation"}]

I've performed a web search for "cooperation." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and General Concept

Cooperation takes place when a group of organisms works or acts together for a collective benefit to the group as opposed to working in competition for selfish individual benefit.(no content)In evolution, cooperation is the process where groups of organisms work or act together for common or mutual benefits.

## Importance to Humans

Every human achievement is actually reliant on the cooperation efforts that have been created by others, from the cursory to the truly magnificent.(no content)Humans are biologically geared to ensuring survival by social instincts like much of the food early human beings ate were hunted or gathered, aspects of cooperation that alone cannot be done.

## Cooperation in Nature

Cooperation is common in non-human animals, with many organisms other than apes, such as fish, birds, and insects exhibiting cooperative behavior: teaching, helping, and self-sacrifice.

## Business Cooperatives

A cooperative is "an autonomous association of persons united voluntarily to meet their common economic, social and cultural needs and aspirations through a jointly owned and democratically-controlled enterprise".(no content)Worker cooperatives are typically more productive and economically resilient than many other forms of enterprise, with twice the number of co-operatives (80%) surviving their first five years compared with other business ownership models (44%).

The search results also include information about various international cooperation organizations, such as the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation and the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "punishment evolution"

Links: [{"title":"Punishment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punishment"},{"title":"History of criminal justice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_criminal_justice"},{"title":"Third-party punishment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third-party_punishment"},{"title":"Discipline and Punish - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discipline_and_Punish"},{"title":"Five Punishments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five_Punishments"},{"title":"Corporal punishment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporal_punishment"},{"title":"Psychological punishment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_punishment"},{"title":"Punishment (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punishment_(psychology)"},{"title":"Beyond Freedom and Dignity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beyond_Freedom_and_Dignity"},{"title":"Altruism (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism_(biology)"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about punishment evolution:

## Evolutionary Origins of Punishment

Punishment is sometimes called retaliatory or moralistic aggression and has been observed in all species of social animals, leading evolutionary biologists to conclude that it is an evolutionarily stable strategy, selected because it favors cooperative behavior.

Evidence of punishment mechanisms exists across various animal species. There is proof of honey bee workers with mutations that make them fertile laying eggs only when other honey bees are not observing them, and the few that are caught in the act are killed. Additionally, primates often have notions of fairness and sharing, with violations punished by exclusion or banishment from social groups.

## Historical Evolution in Human Societies

In human history, the forms and systems of punishment have evolved significantly. Prior to agriculture, more nomadic cultures had systems of punishment for behavior or resistance. With the development of agriculture, which led to more closely populated cities and cultures and behavior to address fears of persons taking advantage of or causing harm to others, more formal systems of punishment for crimes developed.(no content)Hunter-gatherer societies have tended to use little corporal punishment, whereas agricultural and industrial societies tend to use progressively more of it.

## Modern Punishment Systems

The evolution of punishment systems continued into more recent times. The emergence of prison as the form of punishment for every crime grew out of the development of discipline in the 18th and 19th centuries.

Links: [{"title":"Punishment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punishment"},{"title":"History of criminal justice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_criminal_justice"},{"title":"Third-party punishment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third-party_punishment"},{"title":"Discipline and Punish - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discipline_and_Punish"},{"title":"Five Punishments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five_Punishments"},{"title":"Corporal punishment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporal_punishment"},{"title":"Psychological punishment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_punishment"},{"title":"Punishment (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punishment_(psychology)"},{"title":"Beyond Freedom and Dignity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beyond_Freedom_and_Dignity"},{"title":"Altruism (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism_(biology)"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about punishment evolution:

## Evolutionary Origins of Punishment

Punishment is sometimes called retaliatory or moralistic aggression and has been observed in all species of social animals, leading evolutionary biologists to conclude that it is an evolutionarily stable strategy, selected because it favors cooperative behavior.

Evidence of punishment mechanisms exists across various animal species. There is proof of honey bee workers with mutations that make them fertile laying eggs only when other honey bees are not observing them, and the few that are caught in the act are killed. Additionally, primates often have notions of fairness and sharing, with violations punished by exclusion or banishment from social groups.

## Historical Evolution in Human Societies

In human history, the forms and systems of punishment have evolved significantly. Prior to agriculture, more nomadic cultures had systems of punishment for behavior or resistance. With the development of agriculture, which led to more closely populated cities and cultures and behavior to address fears of persons taking advantage of or causing harm to others, more formal systems of punishment for crimes developed.(no content)Hunter-gatherer societies have tended to use little corporal punishment, whereas agricultural and industrial societies tend to use progressively more of it.

## Modern Punishment Systems

The evolution of punishment systems continued into more recent times. The emergence of prison as the form of punishment for every crime grew out of the development of discipline in the 18th and 19th centuries.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "signaling biology"

Links: [{"title":"Cell signaling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cell_signaling"},{"title":"Signal transduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_transduction"},{"title":"Signalling theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signalling_theory"},{"title":"List of signalling pathways - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_signalling_pathways"},{"title":"Biochemical cascade - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biochemical_cascade"},{"title":"Signal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal"},{"title":"Quorum sensing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quorum_sensing"},{"title":"Paracrine signaling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paracrine_signaling"},{"title":"Science Signaling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_Signaling"},{"title":"Intercellular communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intercellular_communication"}]

## Signaling Biology

Signaling biology refers to cellular and biological communication processes. Here are the key aspects:

### Definition and Scope

In biology, cell signaling is the process by which a cell interacts with itself, other cells, and the environment.(no content)Cell signaling is a fundamental property of all cellular life in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

### How Signaling Works

Typically, the signaling process involves three components: the first messenger (the ligand), the receptor, and the signal itself.(no content)In biology, signals are mostly chemical in nature, but can also be physical cues such as pressure, voltage, temperature, or light.

### Types of Signaling Molecules

Chemical signals are molecules with the ability to bind and activate a specific receptor. These molecules, also referred to as ligands, are chemically diverse, including peptides (e.g. insulin, ACTH), lipids, and other compounds. Peptide and lipid ligands are particularly important, as most hormones belong to these classes of chemicals.

### Signal Transduction

A biochemical cascade, also known as a signaling cascade or signaling pathway, is a series of chemical reactions that occur within a biological cell when initiated by a stimulus.(no content)Depending on the efficiency of the nodes, a signal can be amplified (a concept known as signal gain), so that one signaling molecule can generate a response involving hundreds to millions of molecules.

### Types of Cell Signaling

Cell signaling can occur over short or long distances,and can be further classified as autocrine, intracrine, juxtacrine, paracrine, or endocrine.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "reciprocity evolution"

Links: [{"title":"Reciprocity (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(evolution)"},{"title":"Reciprocal altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_altruism"},{"title":"Coevolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coevolution"},{"title":"Social preferences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_preferences"},{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Reciprocal causation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_causation"},{"title":"Reciprocity (social psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(social_psychology)"},{"title":"Altruism (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism_(biology)"},{"title":"Reciprocal altruism in humans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_altruism_in_humans"},{"title":"Cooperation (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation_(evolution)"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of reciprocity evolution:

## Definition and Core Concept

Reciprocity in evolutionary biology refers to mechanisms whereby the evolution of cooperative or altruistic behaviour may be favoured by the probability of future mutual interactions.

## Types of Reciprocity

Direct reciprocity was proposed by Robert Trivers as a mechanism for the evolution of cooperation. If there are repeated encounters between the same two players in an evolutionary game in which each of them can choose either to "cooperate" or "defect", then a strategy of mutual cooperation may be favoured even if it pays each player, in the short term, to defect when the other cooperates.(no content)Downstream reciprocity occurs when the performer of an act of altruism is more likely to be the recipient of a later act of altruism. In other words: A helps B, making it more likely that C will later help A.(no content)Reputation allows evolution of cooperation by indirect reciprocity. Natural selection favors strategies that base the decision to help on the reputation of the recipient: studies show that people who are more helpful are more likely to receive help.

## Reciprocal Altruism

In evolutionary biology, reciprocal altruism is a behaviour whereby an organism acts in a manner that temporarily reduces its fitness while increasing another organism's fitness, with the expectation that the other organism will act in a similar manner at a later time. The concept was initially developed by Robert Trivers to explain the evolution of cooperation as instances of mutually altruistic acts.

## Game Theory Application

The winner was a very simple strategy submitted by Anatol Rapoport called "tit for tat" (TFT) that cooperates on the first move, and subsequently echoes (reciprocates) what the other player did on the previous move.

Here are the search results for "reputation":

## Definition and General Concept

The reputation or prestige of a social entity (a person, a social group, an organization, or a place) is an opinion about that entity – typically developed as a result of social evaluation on a set of criteria, such as behavior or performance.(no content)Reputation is a ubiquitous, spontaneous, and highly efficient mechanism of social control.

## Academic Study

Reputation is a subject of study in social, management, and technological sciences, and its influence ranges from competitive settings, like markets, to cooperative ones, like firms, organizations, institutions and communities.(no content)The concept of reputation is considered important in business, politics, education, online communities, and many other fields, and it may be considered as a reflection of a social entity's identity.

## Corporate Reputation

In business contexts, management scholars describe corporate reputations in two main ways, including the broad view as an aggregation of perceptions that form as audiences judge the behaviors of companies, and the specific view as an assessment by some specific audience of the company's ability to perform or behave in a certain way.

## Related Topics

The search also returned results on reputation-related topics including:
- **Reputation.com**: A business-to-business online reputation management and customer experience management company headquartered in San Ramon, California.
- **Reputation Laundering**: The process where a person or organization conceals unethical, corrupt, or criminal behavior or other forms of controversy by performing highly visible positive actions with the intent to improve their reputation and obscure their history.
- **Music and Culture**: The results also included references to various musical works and albums titled "Reputation" or "Bad Reputation," including Taylor Swift's 2017 album.

Web search results for query: "self-domestication"

Links: [{"title":"Self-domestication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-domestication"},{"title":"Domestication syndrome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestication_syndrome"},{"title":"Domestication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestication"},{"title":"Wild ancestor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wild_ancestor"},{"title":"Domestication theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestication_theory"},{"title":"Domestication of the dog - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestication_of_the_dog"},{"title":"Domestication of vertebrates - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestication_of_animals"},{"title":"Category:Domesticated animals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Domesticated_animals"},{"title":"List of domesticated plants - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_domesticated_plants"},{"title":"De novo domestication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_novo_domestication"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about self-domestication:

## Definition

Self-domestication is a scientific hypothesis that posits the occurrence of a process of artificial selection among human beings, akin to that observed in domesticated animals.

## Human Self-Domestication

Primatologist Richard Wrangham has proposed that humans have "domesticated" themselves through a process of self-selection.(no content)The most comprehensive case for human self-domestication has been proposed for the transition from robust humans such as Neanderthals or Denisovans to anatomically modern humans. This unintentional auto-domestication coincided with the introduction of imagery of female sexuality and occurred simultaneously in four continents then occupied by hominins, leading to rapid changes typical for domestication, such as in cranial morphology, skeletal architecture, reduction in brain volume, to playful and exploratory behavior.

### Addressing the Aggression Paradox

Academics have raised concerns with inconsistencies with the self-domestication hypothesis, pointing out that it isn't logical that humans could potentially be domesticated given the profundity of violent acts for which they are responsible. Reconciling this paradox, Wrangham posited that self-domestication is the outcome of two different kinds of aggression: proactive and reactive aggression.(no content)Generally, humans demonstrate lower aggression within groups, with reactive aggression being much more closely associated with anger and characterized as an immediate response to a threat. Aligned with the behavior of self-domesticated bonobos, humans do not have a high propensity for reactive aggression.

## Other Examples

The concept also applies to other species. In the case of dogs, wolves most likely drawn to human camps were the less-aggressive, subdominant pack members with lowered flight response, higher stress thresholds and less wary around humans, which was the start of a process known as self-domestication, making them better candidates for further domestication.

I've completed a web search for "religion" and found comprehensive information. Here's what the search revealed:

## Definition and Characteristics

Religion is a range of social-cultural systems, including designated behaviors and practices, ethics, morals, beliefs, worldviews, texts, sanctified places, prophecies, or organizations, that generally relate humanity to supernatural, transcendental, and spiritual elements.(no content)Religion differs from private belief in that it has a public aspect.

## Global Distribution

There are an estimated 10,000 distinct religions worldwide, though nearly all of them have regionally based, relatively small followings.(no content)Four religions—Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, and Buddhism—account for over 77% of the world's population.

## Major Religious Traditions

World religions is a socially-constructed category that demarcates religions deemed to have been especially large, internationally widespread, or influential in the development of human societies, typically consisting of the "big five" religions: Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, Islam, and Judaism.

## Components of Religions

Most religions have organized behaviours, including clerical hierarchies, a definition of what constitutes adherence or membership, congregations of laity, regular meetings or services for the purposes of veneration of a deity or for prayer, holy places (either natural or architectural) or religious texts.

Web search results for query: "primates"

Links: [{"title":"Primate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primate"},{"title":"List of primates by population - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_primates_by_population"},{"title":"List of largest non-human primates - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_non-human_primates"},{"title":"Animal testing on non-human primates - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_testing_on_non-human_primates"},{"title":"Evolution of primates - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_of_primates"},{"title":"Primate sociality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primate_sociality"},{"title":"Category:Primates of North America - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Primates_of_North_America"},{"title":"The World's 25 Most Endangered Primates - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_World's_25_Most_Endangered_Primates"},{"title":"List of fictional primates - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fictional_primates"},{"title":"Sexual dimorphism in non-human primates - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_dimorphism_in_non-human_primates"}]

Here's information about primates based on the search results:

## Overview

Primates arose 74–63 million years ago first from small terrestrial mammals, which adapted for life in tropical forests: many primate characteristics represent adaptations to the challenging environment among tree tops, including large brain sizes, binocular vision, color vision, vocalizations, shoulder girdles allowing a large degree of movement in the upper limbs, and opposable thumbs (in most but not all) that enable better grasping and dexterity.

## Diversity and Size

There are 376–524 species of living primates, depending on which classification is used.(no content)Primates range in size from Madame Berthe's mouse lemur, which weighs 30 g (1 oz), to the eastern gorilla, weighing over 200 kg (440 lb).(no content)New primate species continue to be discovered: over 25 species were described in the 2000s, 36 in the 2010s, and six in the 2020s.

## Behavior and Intelligence

Primates are among the most social of all animals, forming pairs or family groups, uni-male harems, and multi-male/multi-female groups.(no content)Primates are also the most cognitively advanced animals, with humans (genus Homo) capable of creating complex languages and sophisticated civilizations, while non-human primates have been recorded using tools.

## Conservation Status

About 60% of primate species are threatened with extinction.(no content)Common threats include deforestation, forest fragmentation, monkey drives, and primate hunting for use in medicines, as pets, and for food. Large-scale tropical forest clearing for agriculture most threatens primates.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "norm psychology social norms"

Links: [{"title":"Social norm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_norm"},{"title":"Social norms approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_norms_approach"},{"title":"Normative social influence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normative_social_influence"},{"title":"Normativity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normativity"},{"title":"Norm of reciprocity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norm_of_reciprocity"},{"title":"Social influence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influence"},{"title":"Norm (philosophy) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norm_(philosophy)"},{"title":"Normalization (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normalization_(sociology)"},{"title":"Normality (behavior) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normality_(behavior)"},{"title":"Norm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norm"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about norms in psychology and social norms:

## Definition and Basic Concept

Social norms refers to the unwritten rules that govern social behavior.(no content)In the field of social psychology, the roles of norms are emphasized—which can guide behavior in a certain situation or environment as "mental representations of appropriate behavior".

## Norm Psychology

Norm psychology examines normative cognition, which encompasses psychological processes involved in learning, following, and enforcing norms. Norms in this context are social rules, often informal and context-dependent, specifying what people may, must, or must not do.(no content)They can be learned explicitly through mentoring or implicitly through observation and inference. Once acquired, norms guide behavior and act as evaluative standards. Additionally, they motivate individuals to teach them to others and punish violations.

## Types of Social Norms

Research in social psychology distinguishes between descriptive norms (what people commonly do) and injunctive norms (what people ought to do).(no content)Injunctive norms reflect people's perceptions of what behaviors are approved or disapproved by others. They assist an individual in determining what is acceptable and unacceptable social behavior.

## Functions and Effects

Social norms have a way of maintaining order and organizing groups.(no content)It has been shown that normative messages can promote pro-social behavior, including decreasing alcohol use, increasing voter turnout, and reducing energy use.(no content)Normative social influence can be a very powerful, yet unconscious, motivator of behavior.

## Enforcement

Social norms can be enforced formally (e.g., through sanctions) or informally (e.g., through body language and non-verbal communication cues).

## Definition and Basic Concept

Social norms refers to the unwritten rules that govern social behavior.(no content)In the field of social psychology, the roles of norms are emphasized—which can guide behavior in a certain situation or environment as "mental representations of appropriate behavior".

## Norm Psychology

Norm psychology examines normative cognition, which encompasses psychological processes involved in learning, following, and enforcing norms. Norms in this context are social rules, often informal and context-dependent, specifying what people may, must, or must not do.(no content)They can be learned explicitly through mentoring or implicitly through observation and inference. Once acquired, norms guide behavior and act as evaluative standards. Additionally, they motivate individuals to teach them to others and punish violations.

## Types of Social Norms

Research in social psychology distinguishes between descriptive norms (what people commonly do) and injunctive norms (what people ought to do).(no content)Injunctive norms reflect people's perceptions of what behaviors are approved or disapproved by others. They assist an individual in determining what is acceptable and unacceptable social behavior.

## Functions and Effects

Social norms have a way of maintaining order and organizing groups.(no content)It has been shown that normative messages can promote pro-social behavior, including decreasing alcohol use, increasing voter turnout, and reducing energy use.(no content)Normative social influence can be a very powerful, yet unconscious, motivator of behavior.

## Enforcement

Social norms can be enforced formally (e.g., through sanctions) or informally (e.g., through body language and non-verbal communication cues).

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Survey

The paper "The Origins and Psychology of Human Cooperation" is classified as a **survey** because it synthesizes and reviews existing evolutionary mechanisms and frameworks rather than proposing new methodologies.

**Key Entities Identified:** 14 concepts

All entities mentioned explicitly in the title and abstract have been extracted and mapped to Wikipedia articles:

1. **Cooperation** - The foundational concept examining mechanisms of human social interaction
2. **Evolutionary biology** - The primary theoretical framework
3. **Psychology** - The discipline studying behavior and mind
4. **Cultural evolution** - How cultures change over time
5. **Kinship** - Blood and social relationships enabling cooperation
6. **Reciprocity (evolution)** - Mutual exchange mechanism
7. **Reputation** - Social status monitoring mechanism
8. **Signalling theory** - Information transmission mechanism
9. **Punishment** - Enforcement mechanism for cooperation
10. **Self-domestication** - Evolutionary hypothesis for human behavior
11. **Social norm** - Rules governing behavior (norm psychology)
12. **Religion** - Institutional framework affecting cooperation
13. **Marriage** - Social system structuring relationships
14. **Primate** - Comparative species for evolutionary analysis

All triples have been validated and the JSON output file meets all requirements. The validation confirms the paper has the required at least 1 "uses" relation (it has 14), and as a survey paper, it correctly has 0 "proposes" relations.

Sources:
- [Cooperation - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation)
- [Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_biology)
- [Psychology - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology)
- [Cultural evolution - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_evolution)
